tools.title: Architecture Diagram Studio
tools.description: Generate draft architecture diagrams from structured inputs.

tools.title: Game Canvas
tools.description: Interactive games with keyboard and touch; offline after first load.

tools.title: Vision Quick Check
tools.description: Validate and preview images; guide on size/format.

tools.title: Speech Sound Analysis
tools.description: Analyze uploaded/recorded audio; transcript and basic metrics.

tools.title: Code Lab
tools.description: Run code safely in a sandbox with allowlisted languages.

tools.title: Python playground
tools.description: Run small Python experiments in-browser (Pyodide).

examples.title: Hello World
examples.expectedOutput: Hello, world!

examples.title: List Comprehension

inputs.code:
nums = [1, 2, 3, 4]
doubled = [n * 2 for n in nums]
print('Doubled:', doubled)

examples.expectedOutput: Doubled: [2, 4, 6, 8]

examples.title: Dictionary Operations
examples.expectedOutput: Alice is 30 years old

tools.explain:
**What this tool does**

Run Python code right in your browser. No installation needed. Just type code and watch it run. It's powered by Pyodide, which is basically Python running in your browser. Pretty cool, right?

**When to use it**

✅ Learning Python
✅ Testing algorithms
✅ Quick calculations
✅ Experimenting with code ideas
✅ Practicing Python syntax

**When NOT to use it**

❌ Reading or writing files
❌ Accessing the internet
❌ Very complex programs
❌ Heavy computations (use your computer instead)

**How to use**

Type your Python code in the box. Click Run. See the output below. That's the whole process.

**Try these**

- Print: `print('Hello, world!')`
- Math: `result = 10 * 5; print(result)`
- Lists: `numbers = [1, 2, 3]; print(numbers)`
- Loops: `for i in range(5): print(i)`

**Safety**

Your code runs in a secure sandbox. Can't access files or internet. Safe as houses.

**Limits**

5 seconds runtime. 256MB memory. 128KB output. Fair enough for practice.

tools.title: JavaScript sandbox
tools.description: Test JS behaviour and parsing safely.

examples.title: Hello World
examples.expectedOutput: Hello, world!

examples.title: Simple Loop
examples.expectedOutput: Sum: 15

examples.title: Array Transform
examples.expectedOutput: Doubled: [2, 4, 6, 8]

tools.explain:
**What this tool does**

Think of this as a safe practice room for code. Like a real sandbox where you can build without making a mess, this tool lets you write and test JavaScript without affecting anything else. Your code runs in a completely isolated space.

**When to use it**

✅ Learning JavaScript
✅ Testing code quickly
✅ Experimenting with ideas
✅ Practicing programming

**When NOT to use it**

❌ Changing webpage elements
❌ Saving or reading files
❌ Accessing the internet
❌ Big projects (use a code editor instead)

**How to use**

Type your code in the box. Click Run. See your results. That's it. Simple.

**Try these**

- Print: `console.log('Hello!')`
- Math: `let x = 5 + 3; console.log(x);`
- Lists: `let list = [1, 2, 3]; console.log(list[0]);`

**Safety**

Your code runs in an isolated space. Completely safe. No way to break anything.

**Limits**

2 seconds runtime. 64KB output. No internet or file access. That's the deal.

tools.title: SQL sandbox (SQLite)
tools.description: Practise queries and joins locally.

examples.title: Select All Users
examples.expectedOutput: Returns all rows from users table

examples.title: Join Query

inputs.query: SELECT u.name, o.amount FROM users u JOIN orders o ON u.id = o.user_id;

examples.expectedOutput: Returns user names with their order amounts

examples.title: Aggregation

inputs.query: SELECT user_id, SUM(amount) as total FROM orders GROUP BY user_id;

examples.expectedOutput: Returns total order amount per user

tools.explain:
**What this tool does**

This is a practice database. Write SQL queries and see results instantly. It comes with sample data already set up, so you can start practicing right away. No need to create tables or load data. Just write queries and go.

**When to use it**

✅ Learning SQL
✅ Testing queries
✅ Practicing joins
✅ Understanding how databases work

**When NOT to use it**

❌ Real production data
❌ Complex multi-table systems
❌ Deleting or changing data structure (DROP and ALTER are blocked for safety)

**How to use**

Write a SQL query in the box. Click Run. See your results in a table. Simple.

**Sample data included**

- `users` table: id, name, email, age
- `orders` table: id, user_id, amount

**Try these**

- Get all users: `SELECT * FROM users;`
- Find specific user: `SELECT * FROM users WHERE name = 'Alice';`
- Join tables: `SELECT u.name, o.amount FROM users u JOIN orders o ON u.id = o.user_id;`

**Safety**

Only safe queries allowed. Dangerous operations are blocked. Can't break anything.

**Limits**

3 seconds runtime. 128MB memory. 256KB output. Good enough for learning.

tools.title: RSA lab (OAEP + SHA-256)
tools.description: Generate keys and explain asymmetric crypto.

examples.title: Generate Key Pair
examples.expectedOutput: Public and private key pair generated

examples.title: Encrypt Message
examples.expectedOutput: Encrypted ciphertext

tools.explain: The RSA lab demonstrates asymmetric cryptography using RSA-OAEP with SHA-256. It lets you generate key pairs, encrypt messages, and decrypt ciphertext. Use it to understand how public-key cryptography works and see the difference between encryption and signing. Don't use it for production cryptographic operations - this is educational. Inputs: action (string) - 'generate', 'encrypt', or 'decrypt'. Limits: 2000ms CPU, 64MB memory, 16KB output. Security: Uses Web Crypto API with strict key size limits.

tools.title: Entropy and hashing
tools.description: Visualise randomness and the avalanche effect.

examples.title: Hash Text
examples.expectedOutput: SHA-256 hash of the input text

examples.title: Avalanche Effect
examples.expectedOutput: Different hash from 'Hello, world!' (demonstrates avalanche effect)

tools.explain: The entropy and hashing tool visualizes randomness and the avalanche effect in cryptographic hash functions. It shows how small changes in input produce completely different hash outputs. Use it to understand hash function properties and verify data integrity concepts. Don't use it for actual cryptographic operations in production. Inputs: input (string) - Text to hash. Limits: 500ms CPU, 32MB memory, 2KB output. Security: Uses Web Crypto API, all processing is local.

tools.title: Password entropy meter
tools.description: Compare length vs complexity trade-offs.

examples.title: Weak Password
examples.expectedOutput: Low entropy, weak strength

examples.title: Strong Password
examples.expectedOutput: Higher entropy, strong strength

examples.title: Very Long Password
examples.expectedOutput: High entropy due to length, even with simple words

tools.explain: The password entropy meter calculates the entropy (randomness) of a password and estimates how long it would take to crack. It considers character set diversity (lowercase, uppercase, numbers, symbols) and length. Use it to understand password strength and compare different password strategies. Don't use it to validate actual passwords in production - this is educational. Inputs: password (string) - The password to analyze. Limits: 100ms CPU, 16MB memory, 1KB output. Security: All processing is local, no data is sent anywhere.

tools.title: Certificate viewer
tools.description: Inspect certificate fields and trust cues.

examples.title: Parse Certificate
examples.expectedOutput: Parsed certificate fields: issuer, subject, validity, etc.

examples.title: View Certificate Details
examples.expectedOutput: Certificate details including validity dates and key information

tools.explain: The certificate viewer parses and displays X.509 certificate fields in a readable format. It shows issuer, subject, validity dates, and key information. Use it to inspect certificates and understand trust chains. Don't use it to validate actual certificates in production. Inputs: certificate (string) - PEM or DER encoded certificate. Limits: 1000ms CPU, 32MB memory, 8KB output. Security: Parsing only, no network validation.

tools.title: Regex tester
tools.description: Extract patterns and groups from sample text.

defaultInputs.text: Contact us at hello@example.com or support@test.org

examples.title: Email Pattern

inputs.text: Contact us at hello@example.com or support@test.org

examples.expectedOutput: Matches: hello@example.com, support@test.org

examples.title: Number Extraction

inputs.text: The price is $42.99 and quantity is 5

examples.expectedOutput: Matches: 42, 99, 5

examples.title: Word Boundaries

inputs.text: The cat sat on the mat. Category is different.

examples.expectedOutput: Matches: cat (but not 'cat' in 'Category')

tools.explain: The regex tester helps you test regular expression patterns against sample text. It shows all matches and captured groups. Use it to debug regex patterns, learn regex syntax, or validate text extraction logic. Don't use it for extremely long text or complex patterns that might timeout. Inputs: pattern (string) - Your regex pattern. text (string) - Text to test against. Limits: 2000ms CPU, 64MB memory, 128KB output. Security: Patterns are executed with timeout protection to prevent ReDoS attacks.

tools.title: Schema inspector
tools.description: Explore entities, fields, and relationships.

inputs.name: schema
inputs.limits: SQL DDL or JSON schema, max 20KB

examples.title: Inspect JSON Schema
examples.expectedOutput: Visual representation of entities, fields, and relationships

examples.title: Explore Complex Schema
examples.expectedOutput: Multiple entities with relationships visualized

tools.explain: The schema inspector visualizes data models from JSON schema definitions. It shows entities, fields, types, and relationships in an explorable format. Use it to understand data structures, plan database schemas, or document existing models. Don't use it for production schema validation. Inputs: schema (string) - JSON schema definition. Limits: 500ms CPU, 64MB memory, 64KB output. Security: JSON parsing only, no execution.

tools.title: Logic gate simulator
tools.description: Learn AND/OR/XOR with truth tables.

examples.title: AND Gate
examples.expectedOutput: Output: true (both inputs true)

examples.title: OR Gate
examples.expectedOutput: Output: true (at least one input true)

tools.explain: The logic gate simulator demonstrates boolean logic operations (AND, OR, XOR, NOT) with interactive truth tables. Use it to understand digital logic fundamentals and see how combinations of gates create circuits. Don't use it for actual circuit design. Inputs: gate (string) - Gate type. inputA, inputB (boolean) - Input values. Limits: 100ms CPU, 16MB memory, 4KB output. Security: Pure boolean logic, no external dependencies.

tools.title: Risk register builder
tools.description: Structure and prioritise risks with likelihood, impact, and mitigations.

examples.title: Create Risk Entry
examples.expectedOutput: Structured risk register entry with priority score

examples.title: Multiple Risks
examples.expectedOutput: Prioritized risk with mitigation suggestions

tools.explain: The risk register builder helps you structure and prioritize risks with likelihood, impact, and mitigation strategies. It generates a prioritized list you can use for risk management planning. Use it to organize risk assessments and track mitigation efforts. Don't use it as a replacement for formal risk management processes. Inputs: riskName, likelihood, impact, mitigations (strings/arrays). Limits: 200ms CPU, 32MB memory, 32KB output. Security: Data processing only, no external storage.

tools.title: Decision log generator
tools.description: Create auditable records of decisions and rationale.

examples.title: Create Decision Log
examples.expectedOutput: Structured decision log with context, alternatives, and rationale

examples.title: Database Choice

inputs.context: Need ACID compliance and complex queries

examples.expectedOutput: Decision log documenting database selection rationale

tools.explain: The decision log generator creates auditable records of architectural and technical decisions. It captures context, alternatives considered, rationale, and consequences. Use it to document important decisions for future reference and team alignment. Don't use it as a replacement for formal ADR processes in large organizations. Inputs: decision, context, alternatives, rationale (strings). Limits: 200ms CPU, 32MB memory, 32KB output. Security: Text processing only.

tools.title: Architecture trade-off analysis
tools.description: Compare options against constraints and non-functional requirements.

examples.title: Compare Options
examples.expectedOutput: Scored comparison table with trade-offs highlighted

examples.title: Deployment Strategy
examples.expectedOutput: Multi-criteria analysis with weighted scores

tools.explain: The architecture trade-off analysis tool helps you compare architectural options against multiple criteria. It generates a scored table that highlights trade-offs and helps make informed decisions. Use it during design reviews to make trade-offs explicit. Don't use it as the sole basis for architectural decisions. Inputs: options, criteria, scores (arrays/objects). Limits: 300ms CPU, 32MB memory, 32KB output. Security: Calculation only.

tools.title: Data classification helper
tools.description: Classify sensitivity and handling requirements in plain terms.

examples.title: Classify Data
examples.expectedOutput: Classification with handling requirements and controls

examples.title: High Sensitivity Data
examples.expectedOutput: Strict classification with encryption and access control requirements

tools.explain: The data classification helper guides you through classifying data sensitivity and determining appropriate handling requirements. It provides plain-language guidance on encryption, access controls, and retention policies. Use it to understand data protection requirements. Don't use it as a replacement for formal data classification policies. Inputs: dataType, sensitivity, context (strings). Limits: 200ms CPU, 32MB memory, 16KB output. Security: Guidance only, no actual data processing.

tools.title: Threat modelling lite
tools.description: Run a STRIDE-style walkthrough without diagrams.

examples.title: STRIDE Analysis
examples.expectedOutput: STRIDE threat analysis report

examples.title: API Service Threats
examples.expectedOutput: Threat analysis focusing on authentication and data protection

tools.explain: The threat modelling lite tool guides you through a STRIDE-style threat analysis without requiring diagrams. It helps identify threats across Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information Disclosure, Denial of Service, and Elevation of Privilege. Use it for quick threat assessments and security reviews. Don't use it as a replacement for formal threat modeling processes. Inputs: systemName, components, dataFlows (strings/arrays). Limits: 500ms CPU, 64MB memory, 64KB output. Security: Analysis only, no external data.

tools.title: Control mapping tool
tools.description: Map controls to standards at a conceptual level (ISO, NIST, SOC 2).

examples.title: Map Control
examples.expectedOutput: Mapping of control to framework requirements

examples.title: Encryption Control
examples.expectedOutput: Cross-framework mapping showing alignment and gaps

tools.explain: The control mapping tool helps you map security controls to standards and frameworks like ISO 27001, NIST CSF, and SOC 2. It shows how controls align across frameworks and identifies gaps. Use it to understand compliance requirements and plan control implementations. Don't use it as a replacement for formal compliance assessments. Inputs: control, frameworks (strings/arrays). Limits: 300ms CPU, 32MB memory, 32KB output. Security: Mapping only, no external validation.

tools.title: Process friction mapper
tools.description: Identify where process slows delivery or creates risk.

examples.title: Map Process Friction
examples.expectedOutput: Friction analysis with bottlenecks and improvement suggestions

examples.title: Deployment Process
examples.expectedOutput: Friction points identified with time estimates and blockers

tools.explain: The process friction mapper helps identify where processes slow delivery or create risk. It visualizes bottlenecks, handoffs, and decision points that create friction. Use it to improve team processes and reduce waste. Don't use it as a replacement for formal process improvement methodologies. Inputs: processName, steps, frictionPoints (strings/arrays). Limits: 300ms CPU, 32MB memory, 32KB output. Security: Analysis only.

tools.title: Technical debt qualifier
tools.description: Describe and prioritise debt with impact, cost, and risk.

examples.title: Qualify Debt
examples.expectedOutput: Prioritized debt item with impact and cost analysis

examples.title: Outdated Dependencies
examples.expectedOutput: Debt qualification with risk assessment and remediation plan

tools.explain: The technical debt qualifier helps you describe and prioritize technical debt with impact, cost, and risk assessments. It generates a prioritized backlog that helps make informed decisions about when to address debt. Use it to make technical debt visible and manageable. Don't use it as a replacement for formal architecture reviews. Inputs: debtItem, impact, cost, risk (strings). Limits: 200ms CPU, 32MB memory, 16KB output. Security: Analysis only.

tools.title: Incident post-mortem builder
tools.description: Create learning-focused post-incident reviews and actions.

examples.title: Create Post-Mortem
examples.expectedOutput: Structured post-mortem template with timeline, root cause, and actions

examples.title: Security Incident
examples.expectedOutput: Security-focused post-mortem with containment steps and prevention measures

tools.explain: The incident post-mortem builder creates learning-focused post-incident review templates. It structures timelines, root causes, impacts, and action items to help teams learn from incidents. Use it to conduct blameless post-mortems and improve reliability. Don't use it as a replacement for formal incident management processes. Inputs: incidentTitle, severity, duration, timeline, rootCause (strings/arrays). Limits: 500ms CPU, 64MB memory, 64KB output. Security: Template generation only.

tools.title: Metrics definition studio
tools.description: Define useful metrics and avoid vanity measurements.

examples.title: Define Metric
examples.expectedOutput: Metric specification with definition, measurement method, and targets

examples.title: Error Rate Metric
examples.expectedOutput: Error rate metric with SLO definition and alerting thresholds

tools.explain: The metrics definition studio helps you define useful metrics and avoid vanity measurements. It guides you through specifying what to measure, how to measure it, and what targets to set. Use it to create meaningful metrics that drive decisions. Don't use it as a replacement for formal metrics frameworks. Inputs: metricName, type, target, measurementMethod (strings). Limits: 300ms CPU, 32MB memory, 32KB output. Security: Specification only.
